e:
>> Consider the template code:

>> public boolean equals(Object other=

>> =
        MyClass that =3D (MyClass) other;
>>         // compare fields or w=
hatever you like

>> I claim that this implementation of equals fully supports the
>>=
 contract of Object#equals, including the subclass/superclass case. If

ou think that is false, then please show us a test consistent with

ontract of Object#equals that this implementation does not pass.
>
>Okay, t=
he equals method in the java.util.Set interface, and the two
>implementatio=
ns HashSet and TreeSet.
>
>According to the Set interface definition of equ=
als, two Sets are equal
>if they have the same size, and all the contents o=
f one are contained
>in the other.
>
>Your approach would return false in t=
he case where you have two sets
>full of the same object, but one is the Ha=
shSet implementation and the
>other is the TreeSet implementations.

The on=
ly real attribute of a Set -- the thing that gives it its value -- is the c=
ontents of the set. Since HashSet and TreeSet only have set contents, it is=
 reasonable to use the same equals() implementation for both. In this case,=
 my version breaks. As you point out, going back to instanceof works in thi=
s case.

>This leads into a discussion of when you should allow subclass
>e=
quality, and when to deny it, which I'd find interesting, but is
>probably =
too far offtopic for this list.

Agreed, although with list traffic being s=
low I don't think anyone can really complain about it. Feel free to continu=
e if you like. :)
